message_1:
In a mall, a survey was conducted to determine the shopping behavior of customers. Data on the amount spent by each customer on five different product categories were gathered. Using cluster analysis, group the customers based on their shopping behavior into three distinct clusters. The amount spent by each customer in each of the five categories are shown below:

Customer | Category 1($) | Category 2($) | Category 3($) | Category 4($) | Category 5($)
--- | --- | --- | --- | --- | ---
1 | 20 | 10 | 15 | 5 | 20
2 | 30 | 20 | 5 | 15 | 5
3 | 10 | 5 | 30 | 5 | 40
4 | 5 | 5 | 10 | 5 | 15
5 | 5 | 20 | 5 | 10 | 5
6 | 20 | 5 | 15 | 5 | 30
7 | 5 | 10 | 5 | 20 | 5
message_2:
To perform cluster analysis, we will use the k-means clustering algorithm. We will group the customers into three distinct clusters based on their shopping behavior. 

Step 1: Normalize the data
To ensure that each category has equal weight in the clustering process, we need to normalize the data. We will use min-max normalization for this purpose.

Normalized value = (Original value - Min value) / (Max value - Min value)

Normalized data:

Customer | Category 1 | Category 2 | Category 3 | Category 4 | Category 5
--- | --- | --- | --- | --- | ---
1 | 0.6 | 0.25 | 0.5 | 0 | 0.6
2 | 1 | 0.75 | 0 | 0.5 | 0
3 | 0.2 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 1
4 | 0 | 0 | 0.2 | 0 | 0.4
5 | 0 | 0.75 | 0 | 0.25 | 0
6 | 0.6 | 0 | 0.5 | 0 | 0.8
7 | 0 | 0.25 | 0 | 0.75 | 0

Step 2: Initialize cluster centroids
We will randomly select three customers as initial cluster centroids.

Cluster 1: Customer 1 (0.6, 0.25, 0.5, 0, 0.6)
Cluster 2: Customer 3 (0.2, 0, 1, 0, 1)
Cluster 3: Customer 5 (0, 0.75, 0, 0.25, 0)

Step 3: Assign customers to the nearest centroid
Calculate the Euclidean distance between each customer and the centroids, and assign each customer to the nearest centroid.

Step 4: Update centroids
Calculate the mean of the customers assigned to each centroid and update the centroid coordinates.

Repeat steps 3 and 4 until the centroids do not change significantly or a predefined number of iterations is reached.

Final Clusters:

Cluster 1: Customer 1, Customer 6
Cluster 2: Customer 3, Customer 4
Cluster 3: Customer 2, Customer 5, Customer 7

So, based on their shopping behavior, the customers can be grouped into three distinct clusters as shown above.
